Guidance Note on Special Trade Transactions & Customs Representation

Customs Representation - 
When Required:
Disputes, SCNs (Show Cause Notices), demand notices, adjudications.
For clarification of classification, valuation, exemptions.
How to Represent:
Engage Customs Broker / Legal Consultant.
Submit written representation with case law references.
Attend personal hearings with complete documentation.
Supporting Documents:
Import/Export Licenses, Contracts, Invoices, Packing List, Bill of Lading/AWB, Bills of Entry/Shipping Bills, Technical Literature.

✅ Do’s & Don’ts Summary:
Do’s - 
Verify product eligibility under FTP.
Keep all customs documents handy (5-year record).
Ensure timely filing of appeals in case of disputes.
Use digital tools like ICEGATE for status tracking.
Don’ts - 
Don’t undervalue goods or misdeclare HSN.
Don’t import second-hand machinery without clearance.
Don’t ignore customs notices (can lead to penalties).
Don’t assume baggage rules cover commercial goods.





Documentation, Fee Structure & Timelines:
Customs Representation
Documents:
Show Cause Notice / Order / Seizure Notice
Import/Export Contracts, Invoices, Shipping Documents
Technical Write-up / HSN Justification
Power of Attorney (if consultant/lawyer represents)
Fee:
Legal/Consultancy fees (₹25,000–₹2,00,000 depending on case).
Appeal fee (Tribunal/Court ~₹5,000–₹20,000).
Timeline:
SCN reply filing: 30 days (extendable).
Adjudication: 3–12 months.
Appeal: 3–6 months.
